text: The present report showed that null mutations of the mouse <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene did not affect the steady-state distribution of splenic DC subsets nor the development and phenotype of BMDC .
However , loss of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> significantly diminished the capacity of BMDC to secrete inflammatory cytokines and nitric oxide .
The attenuated cytokine production was not due to the presence of anti-inflammatory inhibitors , and can be largely explained by selective inactivation of NF-kappaB signaling .
Stimulated cpdm BMDC exhibited Th2-biased T cell-polarizing capabilities , consistent with the Th2 cytokine-dominant phenotype in cpdm mice .

Together , these results indicate an indispensible role of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in regulating DC immunological functions , disruption of which may contribute to the development of immune diseases .
Since WT and cpdm mice are both specific pathogen-free , the nature of the trigger of the severe inflammation in cpdm mice is not obvious .

One such initiating factor could be endogenous apoptotic and / or necrotic cells that can release danger - associated molecular patterns ( DAMPs ) to launch and amplify an inflammatory response [ 32 ] .
Such 'sterile ' inflammation could be initiated and take place in all organs and tissues affected in cpdm mice , thus causing multi-organ inflammatory disorders .
This hypothesis is supported by several recent studies .

Fibroblasts of cpdm mice are highly sensitive to <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced cell death and the cpdm phenotype can be partially rescued by deletion of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 7 ] , [ 8 ] , suggesting that deficiency of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> compromises the anti-apoptotic mechanisms in cpdm mice resulting in cell death - induced inflammatory disease .

text: Apoptosis of keratinocytes is a prominent feature of the skin lesions in cpdm mice [ 33 ] and this is mediated by caspase - dependent mitochondrial pathways [ 34 ] .

These induced and / or intrinsic apoptotic cells can release various types of DAMPs that exert their pro-inflammatory properties by activating DC through pattern recognition receptors [ 32 ] , [ 35 ] , such as <extra_id_0> HMGB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> recognized by <extra_id_0> TLR2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 36 ] , [ 37 ] .

text: Consistent with the impaired Th1 immune response in cpdm mice [ 5 ] , stimulated BMDC weakly polarized Th1 differentiation , but strongly supported the development of Th2 effector cells .

Combined with the dramatic effect of IL12 treatment on the phenotype of these mice [ 5 ] , this suggests that the Th2-biased systemic inflammation in cpdm mice is caused by reduced IL12P70 production from DC .

The importance of IL12P70 in regulating Th1 and Th2 immune responses in mice was clearly demonstrated in <extra_id_0> IL12P35 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - and <extra_id_0> IL12P40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice [ 38 ] , [ 39 ] and through clinical studies in human patients [ 40 ] - [ 42 ] .

text: NF-kappaB , TBK / <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and MAPK signaling are important pathways activated by LPS or poly I : C and disruption of either pathway may lead to decreased cytokine expression .

NF-kappaB activation was selectively inhibited in LPS and poly I : C stimulated cpdm BMDC compared to wild type , while activation of <extra_id_0> TBK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> IRF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> ERK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or p38 was not , indicating that disrupted NF-kappaB signaling in cpdm DC is responsible for the defective cytokine expression .

text: These results seem to contradict a recent study that found increased levels of NF-kappaB activation and IL1 transcription in cpdm mice [ 43 ] .

This difference can probably be attributed to the different cells and tissues used in these studies , and may point to cell - and tissue - type specific functions of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
This is consistent with recent reports of tissue - specific effects of NF-kappaB signaling [ 44 ] .

Ubiquitous activation of NF-kappaB by removing inhibitors such as <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> ITCH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> through genetic manipulation results in widespread inflammation , consistent with the role of NF-kappaB in the production of pro-inflammatory mediators [ 45 ] , [ 46 ] .

However , selective inhibition of NF-kappaB activation in parenchymal cells of the skin , liver , and intestine results in chronic inflammation driven by NF-kappaB competent leukocytes [ 47 ] - [ 50 ] .
This indicates that a balance between the pro-inflammatory role of NF-kappaB in leukocytes and the anti-inflammatory role in parenchymal cells is critical in the maintenance of tissue homeostasis .

Experiments with mice with cell - and tissue - specific deletion of <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , currently under way , will help to elucidate the role of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in inflammation .

Despite defective NF-kappaB activation in the absence of <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression , there was no significant change in splenic DC populations or expression of co-stimulatory molecules on BMDC .

text: Different NF-kappaB subunits involved in the canonical and non-canonical branches of the NF-kappaB signaling pathway have distinct functions to control specific aspects of DC development and function [ 51 ] , [ 52 ] .

The non-canonical pathway ( <extra_id_0> p100 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> processing to produce <extra_id_0> p52 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) appears to be intact in <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cells [ 7 ] , [ 9 ] suggesting that the NF-kappaB heterodimer <extra_id_0> p52 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> RELB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is sufficient to maintain the normal regulation of DC homeostasis and maturation .
The molecular basis by which the <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutation causes reduced NF-kappaB activation in BMDC remains to be determined .

LPS and poly I : C used here are well-defined ligands that specifically engage <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TLR3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , respectively .

text: The expression profile of surface TLR4 complexes is similar between WT and cpdm BMDC suggesting that defective NF-kappaB activation is not a result of differential TLR expression on target cells .

text: The defective NF-kappaB activation by both stimuli suggests that the <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutation interferes with the protein adaptors or kinases shared by both signaling pathways , such as <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 18 ] .

Recent studies demonstrated that <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interacts with <extra_id_0> HOIP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to form LUBAC that exerts its linear-ubiquitin-chain-ligase activity on NF-kappaB signaling players <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 7 ] , an essential step for intact <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated NF-kappaB activation .

text: The <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> null mutation disrupts the ubiquitylation process and abrogates the <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB signaling pathway .

Since TNFR and TLR partially share their downstream signaling cascades , a similar ubiquitin - mediated regulation may hold true for <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in LPS - and poly I : C - induced NF-kappaB activation .

In summary , the present study identified an indispensible role of <extra_id_0> SHARPIN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the production of pro-inflammatory mediators and TLR - induced NF-kappaB signaling .
The impaired Th1-stimulating ability of <extra_id_0> Sharpin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient DC may account for the Th2-dominant inflammatory phenotype of cpdm mice .
The balance between Th1 and Th2 differentiation is critical for immune homeostasis .

A better understanding of how such balance is maintained will help design cytokine treatment for human diseases with Th2-biased cytokine secretion similar to the mouse cpdm , such as allergies and hypereosinophilic syndromes .
